The main benefits of this PR:
- A `wallet.dat` backup, regardless of it's age, can be used to recover all private keys.
- **Basic groundwork for detaching the private-keys from the wallet (allow signing over hardware wallets, etc.)**
Note to test: If encrypting wallet fails for any reason at any late stage, the wallet should retain all unencrypted data.\n

Concept ACK.

I think on-ramping users to this safely/transparently will be the most difficult part.

Warning users that the flag they've set can't be properly used until a new wallet is created(or some migration happens) is a must imo. There needs to be a tool/process to help with that migration, most likely with a backup/cloning step.
Closing in favor of #8035.\nSome parts of this PR could be used to extend HD functionality if and once #8035 has been merged.\n
@jonasschnelli Is it ok to delete the `2016/01/hdsimple` branch from https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/branches now?\n
I deleted the branch. There is still some useful stuff in this branch (thinks like child key derivation by keypath-string) that could be re-used later.\n
Nit: Is there a compelling reason to do this?\n
We no longer translate every time the default changes.\n
Guess it makes sense to use a global or `DEFAULT_` here.\n
Encrypting the wallet does stop the process,... i think this is required.\n
showDetails ought to return Object format even when not generating from a HD key IMO.\n
Probably should make this clear it only happens upon first run of the wallet.\n
Also, `true` is not a valid default value.\n

> 2 is VERSION_SUPPORT_FLAGS...

Not in core... :) But yes. Let me use three.

> showDetails ought to return Object format even when not generating from a HD key IMO.

It shouldn't (`&& pwalletMain->mapKeyMetadata[keyID].keypath.size() > 0`).

> Probably should make this clear it only happens upon first run of the wallet.

I agree, `-hdseed` as startup parameter is somehow not ideal. Not seeding the wallet at first start, would require an additional rpc command (something `generatehdwallet`, `seedwallet`, etc.).

Or an additional "`bitcoin-wallet`" tool that could allow generating and manipulating wallet.dat files.

I'd still prefer the user is warned that they are trying to use hd but already have a running non-hd wallet or simply be disallowed.\n
I'm missing the jump from 3 to 5 here.\n

Right. This PR currently only allows to use hd when no wallet.dat file is present (wallet creation phase). IMO this could be a save start,... first release that includes HD option should probably silently offer the feature with a more or less in-prominent startup argument.\nBut agree, if someone passes `-usehd` while the current wallet is present and does not support HD, we should warn.\n
